f6_assessments.q0:

f6_assessments.q0: In my opinion, the challenge question could have been better formulated, since it sounded ambiguous and could create confusion among potential proposers. Based on the brief section, you can understand the focus that the author is trying to convey with this challenge. From that perspective, I agree with it and find it aligned with the goals of Cardano. In terms of compliance with the strategic goals for the next challenge I find indirect compliance in the sense that if it seeks to improve collaboration for a better distribution of focus and resources helps the growth and strengthening of the ecosystem, however, I would recommend the author to review the challenge setting so that they can make a direct association with the strategy, if possible with more than one goal. Based on my previous analysis, I assign a score of 4.
f6_assessments.q1: Although the community generally puts a lot of effort into trying to improve the gaps that are associated with Catalyst governance, from the perspective of feasibility, I am concerned that there are several challenges that could overlap with this challenge, and this could result in a community's capacity being spread across a number of challenges and as a consequence fail to respond at the level that is expected. This dispersion in community capacity may also result in treasury resources not being allocated in the most efficient way possible.
f6_assessments.q2: The success criteria for the challenge are clearly defined with the right focus, and they fulfill their function of providing guidance to potential applicants seeking funding through this challenge. The same applies to the suggested success metrics. There are three and all of them seem to be accurate and easy to measure. Congratulations! My score is 5.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge question is very popular by the Catalyst community (every week the community hears and asks this question during Town Halls), but I believe it doesn't serve as well in the context described in this challenge.

This challenge setting, if evaluated by itself,  is not critical in the Cardano mission, but the use of tools and services can contribute as auxiliary means to other challenges and proposals and in this context it becomes something important.

The project Catalyst now involves thousands of people. Coordinating work, ideas and initiatives among so many people can be chaos without frameworks, tools and auxiliary services. Without tools, the very work that community advisors (the people who are writing these assessments) do would be less productive, something that today could harm the entire project Catalyst voting model, so the use of tools is something complementary but of great importance for Catalyst and Voltaire being able to advance.

Although this challenge does not have such a strong connection with the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals, there is a relevant relationship with the three items, since the creation/use of tools usually ends up having an open source approach, it also involves people to work in a close to the development of Catalyst and with potential to contribute with dapps and the development ecosystem
f6_assessments.q1:
The development of tools and services has been going on since Catalyst's inception and dozens of people are or have contributed to it. Due to the iterative nature of Catalyst, changes are constant and tools, guidelines need constant updating, so the demand for this type of challenge is regular.

I'm not as confident with the capacity of the Cardano community to fill the budget with high quality proposal because if there are other challenges that can accept this type of proposal (something that usually happens in Catalyst) this challenge may have a depletion of proposals. There is no mention of a defined challenge team.
f6_assessments.q2: The key metrics for evaluating success in this challenge are relevant, but few. I would recommend including more metrics that allow a more complete assessment, especially in relation to the quality of the tools and services that would be developed. The definition of success is objective.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge is for proposals that provide tooling and services to proposals. Alignment is evaluated based on two set of metrics that define whether a given challenge is critical to achieving Cardano’s mission: the fund9 strategic goals and the guiding questions for challenge setting.

In terms of the former, this challenge may prepare groups to contribute to the ecosystem. However, it is not obviously making Cardano an open-sourced ecosystem. Moreover, it is only accelerating the developer and dapp ecosystem insofar as it significantly improves the proposer experience. 

As a proposer who has gotten funded in f6, f7 and is proposing in fund8, and CA/vCA since fund6, I don’t see that there is such a great gap between what tooling could exist and what currently exists. Hence the marginal added value in terms of accelerating the developer and dApp ecosystem through improving the proposal tooling is low in my view.
f6_assessments.q1: There is room for the Cardano community to solve these problems and improve the proposal process. This has been shown by the catalyst school amongst other community initiatives. With that said, however, it is unlikely that the community will have enough ideas so as to fill up at $500k budget. Moreover, many of the problems with the process have been solved effectively through grassroots community efforts in collaboration with the IOHK teams responsible for the Catalyst process. Changes to the ideascale UI has been made and challenge teams are also paid to improve the process. It is therefore highly feasibile in the sense that it is already being done to a very large extent! So strictly speaking, I have to give 5 stars, but voters should be aware of the fact that the community is dealing with it!
f6_assessments.q2: There are three metrics proposed. Number of tooling and service related proposals, tools used by other communities and events arranged to explore new collaboration tools. These are measurable, but does not really weigh into the end goal of collaboration: the output itself. We must be able to assess whether or not these proposals added value in terms of quality products and proposer user experience. This would be more suitable given that the challenge is aimed at improving management and services to proposals.

importance: Innovation funds provide an excellent way to understand how funds can be used to transform our knowledge into intention.
success: Creation of tools, services, and guides that help large communities to distribute focus and resources.
